title: Two people grab the same coat
vignette: Reuven and Shimon simultaneously seize a coat in the market, each shouting “It’s mine!” No proof exists who owned it before this moment.

options.text: Sell or appraise the coat and split the value equally.
Hold the coat until one party brings evidence of ownership.

title: Mixed cash deposits
vignette: A shopkeeper received two sealed bags, one with $100 and one with $200. He forgot which customer gave which.

options.text: Return $100 to each; lock the extra $100 in escrow until the truth is known.
The shopkeeper must compensate the full loss from his own pocket.

title: Finder before the owner knows
vignette: Leah picks up a bracelet she suspects was just lost. The owner has not yet realized it is missing.

options.text: Leah may keep it now—owner will inevitably give up hope.
Leah must wait until the owner notices and despairs before claiming it.

title: Lost object during paid work
vignette: A farmhand spots a lost wallet while on her employer’s time. Picking it up takes only a moment.

options.text: The wallet belongs to the worker—finds are not part of her wage.
The wallet belongs to the employer, who effectively ‘owns’ the worker’s hand during the shift.

title: One canteen in the desert
vignette: Two travellers have water only for one person to survive the trek to safety.

options.text: Share the water equally, risking both lives.
The canteen’s owner drinks it alone to ensure one life is saved.

title: Over-loaded donkey collapse
vignette: A passer-by sees a stranger’s donkey that collapsed because it was overloaded by its owner.

options.text: Help unload even though the owner caused the problem.
Decline; the owner’s negligence removes your duty to assist.

title: What seals a sale?
vignette: Buyer paid but has not yet pulled the goods from the seller’s yard. Fire breaks out.

options.text: Payment already transferred ownership; loss is buyer’s.
Only physical removal finishes the deal; loss is seller’s.

title: How much price fraud voids a sale?
vignette: A vendor overcharges 17 % above market price.

options.text: Any deviation over 16 % cancels the sale; refund in full.
Up to one-third deviation is tolerated; buyer keeps item with partial refund.

title: Hidden interest gift-loan
vignette: Lender gives a ‘gift’ before the loan and borrower promises a similar gift afterward.

options.text: Treat as forbidden interest—repay without extras.
Allowed if no timing is fixed in advance; gifts are voluntary.

title: Borrowed animal conscripted by troops
vignette: A borrowed mule is seized for army service.

options.text: Borrower bears the loss unless the mule is returned.
Loss depends on which direction the troops led it—sometimes owner’s risk.

title: Forbidden route for hired donkey
vignette: Hirer takes the animal down a risky path the owner forbade but claims the danger was gone.

options.text: Believe the hirer; no liability if path was safe.
Hirer pays—unauthorized route change is negligence.

title: Workers snacking in the field
vignette: Harvesters may eat produce while working. How much is fair?

options.text: Unlimited eating allowed during picking.
Limit consumption to the value of their wage.

title: Timely wages
vignette: Day labourer finishes at sunset; employer can’t pay until next morning.

options.text: Payment deadline is sunrise—employer is still on time.
Wages are due the same night; delay violates dignity.

title: Four custodians liability
vignette: Unpaid guardian, paid guardian, renter, borrower each face an unavoidable loss of the item they hold.

options.text: Only borrower always pays; others swear they weren’t negligent.
Switch which keepers swear or pay; higher pay means higher risk.

title: Share-cropper blight
vignette: Blight ruins half the crop on leased land.

options.text: Landowner bears the loss—it’s his soil.
Tenant bears it—he accepted crop risk for a percentage.

title: Clearing the communal canal
vignette: Silt blocks a canal serving upper and lower towns.

options.text: Lower town digs first; they suffer water loss immediately.
Upper town must dig; otherwise no water reaches anyone.

title: Cost of a privacy fence
vignette: One neighbor wants a solid wall, the other refuses to split costs.

options.text: Force both to share wall expenses—privacy benefits all.
Each builds only on their side; no compulsion.

title: New window facing courtyard
vignette: Reuven cuts a window overlooking Levi’s yard.

options.text: Levi can veto—loss of privacy is damage.
If window is high enough, no harm—building allowed.

title: Squatter’s rights
vignette: Ruth lives rent-free in an empty apartment; owner is unaware and suffers no loss.

options.text: Permitted—"benefit without cost" requires no rent.
Forbidden—use of property without consent is theft.

title: Words vs. money fraud
vignette: Merchant humiliates a customer publicly but overcharges him only $1.

options.text: Verbal harm is worse than small monetary fraud.
Both wrongs are equal; Torah parallels them.

title: Consecrating a disputed bathhouse
vignette: Mid-argument, one side declares the jointly-used bath “property of the Temple.”

options.text: Consecration works instantly; rival loses access.
Sanctification fails while ownership is in doubt.

title: Promissory note tug-of-war
vignette: Lender and borrower each clutch the same loan document; lender says “not repaid,” borrower says “paid.”

options.text: Divide the face value and each swears.
Note is indivisible—decide entirely for one party based on evidence.

title: “Pick it up for me!”
vignette: Rachel sees a watch on the ground and orders Dan: “Please lift it for me.”

options.text: Rachel acquires it through Dan’s act of agency.
Dan keeps it; agency without prior consent fails.

title: Minor or servant acquires for third party
vignette: A child lifts a lost coin “for Grandma.”

options.text: Child can acquire for another—even if legally dependent.
Dependent’s hand belongs to guardian; coin goes to guardian by default.

title: Three coins stacked—identifying mark?
vignette: Finder discovers exactly three coins neatly stacked.

options.text: Number pattern is a strong identifying mark; must announce.
Raw number alone is not a mark; finder may keep.

title: Bailee repaid, thief found: who gets double?
vignette: Guardian already reimbursed owner for a stolen vase. The thief is now caught and must pay double.

options.text: Owner receives the penalty—he bore the loss.
Guardian receives it; he is now the injured party.

title: Guardian transfers deposit
vignette: Unpaid guardian silently hands the item to another keeper; item is lost.

options.text: Original guardian liable—he altered terms.
New guardian liable once he accepts custody.

title: Earnest-money forfeiture
vignette: Buyer gives 20 % deposit with clause: backing out forfeits deposit.

options.text: Clause stands; deposit is lost if buyer retracts.
Forfeiture clause is void—over-optimistic pledge never sticks.

title: Boss vs. laborer retract first
vignette: At 7 a.m. laborers and boss agree on a day’s work. By 7 : 10 both sides find better offers.

options.text: Laborers may quit without penalty; their reliance trumps.
Owner’s loss is greater; laborers must stay or compensate.

title: Iron-sheep investment
vignette: Investor guarantees principal goat’s value while keeping all offspring profits.

options.text: Treated as hidden interest—prohibited arrangement.
Allowed if risk is genuinely shared.

title: Mountain vs. valley path hire
vignette: Hirer detours donkey from agreed valley path to a mountain path of equal length; donkey breaks a leg.

options.text: Any unauthorized route change is negligence; hirer pays.
Liability only if new path is objectively rougher.
